Review Recent advances in electrocatalytic conversion of nitrates into high-value products Yuhao Qian Writing – original draft a b Jiabao Lv Writing – review & editing a Xuting Liu Writing – review & editing a Zhifu Qi Conceptualization b ⁎ Angjian Wu Conceptualization a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Clean Energy Utilization, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, Zhejiang, China State Key Laboratory of Clean Energy Utilization Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang 310027 China State Key Laboratory of Clean Energy Utilization, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, Zhejiang, China b Baima Lake Laboratory, Hangzhou 310053, Zhejiang, China Baima Lake Laboratory Hangzhou Zhejiang 310053 China Baima Lake Laboratory, Hangzhou 310053, Zhejiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract This review comprehensively presents recent advancements in the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrates to high value-added products, while also outlining future challenges and potential perspectives in the field. The electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) powered by renewable energy offers a promising approach for simultaneously reutilization of nitrate and synthesizing high-value products. Nevertheless, theoretical understanding of reaction mechanism was relative illusive, which is indispensable to rationally design of efficient catalysts. Besides, tuning the reaction microenvironment along with the scale-up device development is essential to promote the industrial deployment of electrocatalytic nitrate conversion, while relative research was overlooked. In this regard, recent advances in ammonia synthesis are firstly summarized, including the identification of active sites, exploration of the underlying reaction mechanisms, electrolyzer design and technical-economic analysis. Furthermore, electrocatalytic C–N coupling based on NO3RR to produce higher-value products such as urea and amino acids are also reviewed, to extend the application potential and economic feasibility. Finally, we highlight the existing challenges and the demand of future research for NO3RR. This review anticipates to provide insights into synthesis of high-value products via NO3RR, bridging the gap from laboratory research to industrial fabrication. Keywords Nitrate reduction reaction Electrocatalysis Ammonia synthesis C–N coupling 1 Introduction Nitrogen is of great significance to nature and human activities [1,2]. Despite rich nitrogen existing in nature, normally in inert form as nitrogen gas (N2), it is challenging for direct utilization due to stable N≡N bond (946 kJ mol−1) [3,4]. In the ecosystems, microorganisms primarily can effectively facilitate nitrogen fixation by transforming it into bioavailable nitrogen as ammonia (NH3) [5]. Besides, lighting also contributes to conversion of N2 by generation of nitrogen oxide. However, the demands of agricultural and industrial sectors surpass the capacity of natural nitrogen fixation with the progression of human civilization, driving the fast development of artificial nitrogen fixation over last century [6,7]. Currently, the predominant method for nitrogen fixation in industry is the Haber-Bosch Process (HBP), which utilizes N2 and H2 as raw materials to catalytic synthesize NH3 under high temperature (400–550 °C) and pressure (15–30 MPa) [8,9]. However, this process incurs significant energy consumption, amounting to 1%–2% of the world's energy supply, with substantial carbon dioxide emissions [10,11]. Furthermore, the HBP typically necessitates large-scale and centralized facilities, imposing significant demands on capital investment and spatial requirements [12]. Therefore, it is highly imperative to develop sustainable and efficient nitrogen fixation strategies towards carbon-neutral society. Recently, various methods encompassing photo/electrocatalysis [13], enzyme catalysis [14], and homogeneous catalysis [15] are proposed, aiming at mitigation the reliance on fossil energy and environmental risk. Amongst, nitrogen fixation via electrocatalysis has emerged as a prominent research hotspot, due to its ability to facilitate one-step synthesis of high-value products at ambient temperature and pressure through meticulous catalyst design and adaptable control of the reaction microenvironment [3,15,16]. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) employs N2 and H2O as raw materials [17,18]. However, the high bond energy combined with low solubility of N2 dramatically decrease the reaction activity and product selectivity of NRR [19–22]. In contrast, the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) has garnered considerable interest to overcome the limit of intrinsic activation and mass transfer [16,23,24]. The N–O bond in nitrate exhibits a lower bond energy (204 kJ mol−1), rendering it more susceptible to be activated thus favoring reaction kinetics [25,26]. Moreover, NO3 − serves as an environmental pollutant associated with various diseases and environmental issues, and NO3RR offers the dual benefit of mitigating NO3 − pollutants while generating high-value nitrogen-containing products [27,28]. Nevertheless, NO3RR encounters several challenges, as NO3RR consists of complex reaction process involving multi-step proton and electron transfers. With the generation of various intermediate species, competitive reaction might occur at the catalyst interface affected by the microenvironment [15,29,30]. The cathodic half-reactions for the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate to ammonia are delineated below [31]. N O 3 - + 10 H + + 8 e - ↔ N H 4 + + 3 H 2 O Due to the complexity and diversity of the process, multiple competing reactions occur together. The main competition reactions are as follows. N O 3 - + 2 H + + 2 e - ↔ N O 2 - + H 2 O N O 3 - + 4 H + + 3 e - ↔ N O g + 2 H 2 O 2 N O 3 - + 12 H + + 10 e - ↔ N 2 g + 6 H 2 O N O 3 - + 8 H + + 6 e - ↔ N H 3 O H + + 2 H 2 O H + + e - ↔ 1 2 H 2 g The earliest research on electrocatalytic NO3RR can be traced back to 1981 [32]. Following a series of feasibility studies and reaction mechanism analyses, the understanding on electrocatalytic NO3RR has now become mature. Currently, most research endeavors in NO3RR are predominantly concentrated on the development of efficient catalysts to increase selectivity and yield of NH3. Moreover, novel electrochemical devices are also explored to tailor for high current density and continuous production processes in light of the industrial-scale applications. Even though, economic feasibility poses another limitation on the advancement of NO3RR for ammonia synthesis. Industrially, nitric acid and nitrate are typically obtained through the oxidation of ammonia via nitrification [33]. This implies that the cost of NH3 is generally lower than that of NO3 −, rendering direct industrial nitrate electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis economically unviable. Consequently, reutilizing NO3 − from the environment is supposed to address this issue [13,16]. On the other hand, to synthesize higher-value products, such as urea, amino acids, and so forth from nitrate was also considered as a route to tackle the economic challenge. These products typically contain carbon elements, necessitating the introduction of additional carbon sources for co-reduction with NO3 −, such as carbon dioxide (CO2) and its derivatives (oxalic acid, pyruvic acid, etc.), achieving the C–N coupling [30,34]. This process can not only facilitate the production of high-value products with a green and zero-carbon way, but also enable the recycling of CO2 derived from carbon capture [35,36]. However, the research on nitrate-based electrochemical C–N coupling is still in its infancy, including identifying and designing efficient catalysts, as well as comprehending the reaction mechanism and exploring reaction pathways. In Fig. 1 , we summarized the development history of NO3RR, including both the direct synthesis of ammonia and the C–N coupling for the synthesis of high-value products. In this article, we provide a comprehensive review of the recent advancements in NO3RR (Fig. 2 ). Our focus lies on elucidating the theoretical advancements, catalytic mechanisms, and reaction pathways associated with NO3RR, along with highlighting the progress in catalyst development. Moreover, we focused on the recent advances of large-scale ammonia synthesis via NO3RR. We summarized the latest progress in application of new electrolysis devices in ammonia synthesis and elaborated on the most recent analyses of the technical economics associated with this approach. Concluding remarks encapsulate the existing hurdles while outlining prospective pathways for further exploration, with the overarching aim of fostering deeper understanding and encouraging ongoing research in the realm of electrocatalytic NO3RR. 2 Ammonia synthesis via NO3RR Currently, a large number of literatures has explored the reaction mechanisms, theoretical approaches, and catalyst design strategies for ammonia electrosynthesis from nitrate, and have been extensively examined and consolidated [1,2,11,16,37–40]. In this section, we discuss in depth the mechanisms and theories of NO3RR for ammonia synthesis and latest advancements in high-performance electrocatalyst design. Furthermore, we seek for a prospective way to large-scale ammonia synthesis, thereby charting potential pathways towards the industrialization of ammonia electrosynthesis from nitrate. 2.1 Mechanisms of NH3 synthesis The mechanism of electrocatalysis nitrate reduction entails intricate multi-electron pathways, with diverse stable nitrogen intermediates and products (Fig. 3 ). It is widely recognized that nitrate reduction comprises three pivotal stages [30]: (1) nitrate adsorption (NO3 − → *NO3); (2) Intermediate reactions on the electrocatalyst surface (involving multiple deoxygenation and hydrogenation steps); (3) Ammonia desorption (*NH3 → NH3). At the stage of NO3 − adsorption, the mass transfer of NO3 − to the electrode surface constrains the concentration of NO3 − available for surface adsorption, thereby limiting the overall electrochemical nitrate reduction rate [41,42]. Upon adsorption to the electrode, the rate-determining step (RDS) on most electrodes is usually the reduction of NO3 − to NO2 − [43,44]. The reduction of NO3 − to NO2 − follows a three-step electrochemical-chemical-electrochemical (ECE) mechanism, which involves an initial electron transfer step, followed by a homogeneous chemical reaction that generates more readily reducible species [45,46]. After the generation of NO2 −, *NO serves as another crucial intermediate in subsequent reactions. The generation of NH3 is usually considered to originate from the *NO hydrogenation, while other reaction pathways may result in the formation of other nitrogen-containing species [47,48]. The reaction path of NO3RR is influenced by a variety of factors. For instance, different concentration of NO3 − may influence the reaction mechanism of NO3RR. In conditions characterized by high concentration (>1 M NO3 −) and high acidity (pH<0), NO3 − is predominantly reduced through indirect autocatalytic reduction, with no direct involvement of nitrate ions in the electron transfer reduction process, while at low concentrations (<1 M NO3 −), nitrate engages in the electron transfer process and undergoes reduction to nitrite [49–51]. Additionally, the pH value will also have an impact on the reaction path. Pérez-Gallent et al. observed that the reduction of nitrate on copper is a pH-dependent process [52]. When an acidic electrolyte is utilized, it yields NO and NH4 +, whereas an alkaline electrolyte leads to the formation of NO2 − and NH2OH. In general, the research of mechanism on electrocatalytic NO3RR ammonia synthesis is mature, with the reaction pathway, rate-determining steps, and key reaction intermediates being widely discussed and recognized. However, due to the complexity of the reaction, discrepancies exist between the actual reaction process and theoretical predictions in some situations. Therefore, further exploration of the reaction mechanism is necessary. Additionally, accurate in-situ characterization can accurately identify reaction intermediates and enhance our understanding of the key intermediate conversion processes. 2.2 Advances in NH3 synthesis catalyst design In addition to the factors previously discussed that influence the reaction pathway, the adsorption capacity of different active species on the catalyst surface, as well as the activation energy of intermediate processes, can also affect the reaction activity and selectivity in ammonia synthesis. Liu et al. conducted density functional theory (DFT) calculations to elucidate the trends in NO3RR activity across different metals [53]. The results indicate that Fe and Co have the lowest dissociation barriers for intermediates NO3*, NO2*, NO*, and N2O*, which are crucial in the ammonia synthesis process. In contrast, Ag and Au demonstrate the lowest barrier for N2* formation, leading to the synthesis path to other products (Fig. 4 a–c). Kani et al. calculated the active volcano plots of electrochemical NO3RR and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) for various transition metals [54]. The computational findings indicate that the protonation steps involving *NO2 to *NO2H and *NO to *NOH are the most challenging, and Co and Ni exhibit promising activity due to their favorable binding energies for both steps (Fig. 4d–e). Hu et al. observed that the variations in the local coordination environment on the surfaces and the electronic states of surface atoms account for the disparities in NO3RR [55]. Over all the crystal surface, Cu (100) exhibits the broadest pH range for NO3RR activation, while Cu (111) demonstrates the highest activity in neutral or alkaline environments. Wang et al. substantiated the feasibility of NO3RR on single-atom catalysts (SACs) supported by graphene through high-throughput DFT calculations (Fig. 4f) [56]. The results indicate that the Os SAC emerges as the most promising candidate among all the transition metal SACs. Wang et al. employed DFT simulations to investigate the feasibility, activity, and selectivity of the TM-N4/C catalyst for NO3RR [57]. In catalytic activity, Cu-N4/C and Pt-N4/C exhibit the highest efficiency for NO3RR. Regarding product selectivity, Re-N4/C demonstrates the highest tendency to form NH3, while Pt-N4/C exhibits the highest tendency to form N2. It can be seen that a variety of factors, including the selection of RDS and catalyst models, can lead to the different results of the calculation. Consequently, there is no definitive conclusion regarding which metal exhibits the best catalytic performance. Currently, metal catalysts commonly used in in NO3RR predominantly include precious metals such as ruthenium (Ru), along with transition metals like titanium (Ti), cobalt (Co), nickel (Ni), and copper (Cu). The following sections will provide a detailed enumeration and summary of some commonly used metal catalysts. Ruthenium (Ru) based catalysts have been recognized for their high activity in ammonia synthesis, with numerous studies documenting their effectiveness [58–62]. Due to its high cost, Ru usually be supported on materials with high surface areas to catalyze reactions, either individually or through synergistic effects with other metals. Li et al. designed strained ruthenium nanoclusters to electrocatalysis NO3RR for ammonia synthesis [58]. The introduction of oxygen dopants expands the unit cell of ruthenium, inducing tensile strain. This strain promotes the generation of reactive species, particularly the strain-induced H, which accelerates the electrocatalytic conversion. Wang et al. employed a one-pot solvothermal approach to fabricate RuMo alloy nanoflowers (NFs) featuring a unique face-centered cubic (fcc) phase with a heterogeneous phase consisting of hexahedral and face-centered cubic structures [59]. In-situ characterization and theoretical calculations reveal that the interaction between Ru and Mo and the activity of the fcc phase results in the highest d-band center and exceptional electrocatalysis activity of fcc RuMo NFs. The optimized electronic structure of fcc RuMo NFs facilitates strong adsorption of key intermediates while mitigating competitive hydrogen evolution, thereby underpinning their outstanding performance in NO3RR. Jiang et al. reported the in-situ fabrication of ultrafine amorphous ruthenium nanoclusters uniformly distributed on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) via a facile room temperature chelation co-reduction technique [60]. The amorphous Ru nanoclusters possess numerous low-coordination atoms, which can offer a greater number of catalytic sites than crystalline Ru. Due to its high cost, Ru-based catalysts are not feasible for large-scale industrial applications, prompting researchers to explore alternative materials to replace Ru. Co-based catalysis have been widely noticed due to their cost-effectiveness and high catalytic activity [54,63–70]. Kani et al. employed DFT calculation to assess the NO3RR activity trends of diverse transition metals, concluding that Co and Ni exhibit the highest likelihood of activity [54]. Subsequent experimental verification of the activity in NO3RR confirmed that Co exhibited superior activity, achieving an NH3 faradaic efficiency (FE) of 93.5% and an NH3 current density of 298 mA cm−2. Yang et al. investigated the reaction mechanism of Co-based catalyst electrocatalytic NO3RR synthesis of ammonia using CoP, Co, and Co3O4 as model materials [63]. Under low overpotential, both CoP@Co and Co undergo a three-step relay mechanism, which includes the spontaneous redox between Co and NO3 −, the electroreduction of Co(OH)2 to Co, and the electrocatalytic conversion of NO2 − to NH3. In this process, dynamic Co δ + acts as an active species on the surface. At high overpotentials, a continuous hydrogenation mechanism from NO3 − to NH3 occurs on the surface Co species of both CoP@Co and Co. In contrast, Co3O4 species stably and robustly catalyze the hydrogenation and deoxygenation of NO3 − to NH3 at both low and high overpotentials. Yang et al. synthesized pyridine nitrogen-doped carbon-modified Co nanocrystals (Co/PN-C), leading to significant electrocatalytic NO3RR activity [64]. In-situ Raman and FTIR confirmed that the high activity of Co/PN-C was occasioned by the promotion of NO3 − adsorption and the hydrogenation from *NH to NH3. Besides Co, Ni-based catalysis have also been reported for NO3RR [71–75]. Zhou et al. introduced a defect engineering strategy at the grain boundaries (GBs) of nickel nanoparticles to catalyze NO3RR [71]. Experimental and computational simulations revealed that GBs effectively suppress the HER by favoring the consumption of H* in the NO3RR pathway over hydrogen formation. Hai et al. incorporated nickel into a cobalt metal-organic framework (Co-MOF), leading to enhanced adsorption of NO3 − on NiCoO2@Cu and facilitating electrocatalytic NO3RR [72]. Fe-based catalysts have garnered extensive attention and have been widely reported in electrocatalytic NO3RR due to their unique characteristics in the Haber-Bosch process [76–79]. Inspired by the Fe active sites in both Haber-Bosch catalysts and nitrogenase enzymes, Wu et al. designed Fe SACs for NO3RR, demonstrating excellent activity and selectivity in electrocatalytic performance [76]. DFT simulations revealed that the potential limiting steps are the reduction of NO* to HNO*, and that Fe SACs possess efficient active sites, reducing the thermodynamic barriers of these steps. The conclusion was further confirmed by Li et al. [78]. By combining DFT calculations with in-situ spectroscopic techniques, they found that the Fe single site can facilitate the formation of *NHO from *NO. Moreover, the strong adsorption of NO3 − by single Fe atom sites can effectively inhibit the occurrence of the HER and promote the formation of *NO. Copper (Cu) is also commonly employed in NO3RR owing to its excellent conductivity and limited propensity for hydrogen evolution [29,80–83]. For instance, Liu et al. synthesized a self-supported catalyst (Cu/PTS) for NO3RR to ammonia synthesis [84]. Operando ATR-FTIRAS identified intermediate species such as NO2 −, NO, and NH2, which suggests that the NO3RR on Cu/PTS follows the classical reaction pathway of deoxygenation and hydrogenation. Nonetheless, copper catalysts typically demonstrate inadequate corrosion resistance and diminished NH3 FE [85]. Hence, researchers have shifted their focus towards bimetallic catalysts, aiming to enhance catalytic stability by incorporating additional metals and to improve catalytic activity through the synergistic interaction between different metal species [86]. Sheng et al. effectively provided hydrogen radicals by incorporating Co sites, which facilitated the establishment of a dynamic balance of active hydrogen [87]. Due to the distinctive properties, a superior performance in NO3RR is achieved in ultra-low nitrate concentrations. Titanium (Ti) based materials possess inherent nontoxicity, cost-effectiveness, and excellent stability, along with its low activity to the HER, rendering them as ideal candidates [88,89]. McEnaney et al. found that the advantageous electrochemical characteristics of the titanium electrode, coupled with effective electrolyte engineering, ensure a plentiful supply of NO3 − and H+, thereby enhancing the selectivity towards NH3 [90]. Liu et al. illustrated the enrichment of TiH2 on the near-surface, which was evidenced by in-situ GIXRD and XAS [91]. This quantitative correlation streamlines the electrochemical processing of titanium to yield TiH2/Ti electrodes for NO3RR. Nevertheless, akin to aluminum, titanium exhibits a pronounced passivation tendency, swiftly developing a robust oxide layer in atmospheric conditions and oxidizing or neutral aqueous environments. Consequently, precise identification of active sites is imperative when employing titanium-based materials as catalysts. Another titanium-containing substance, TiO2, has garnered significant attention due to its diverse crystal structures [92–99]. Its suitability as a host for active materials stems from its affordability, non-toxicity, and resistance to corrosion [88]. Chen et al. devised a synthesis strategy integrating copper oxide-derived nanopolycrystalline copper (NPC Cu) with Ti3+ self-doped TiO2 nanotube array (NTA) to fabricate NPC Cu/H-TiO2 NTA [92]. The amalgamation of Ti3+-self-doped TiO2 NTA and NPC Cu facilitates electron transfer and mass transport while engendering copious active sites. The distinctive nanoarchitecture, featuring Cu nanopolycrystals interspersed within TiO2 nanotubes, expedites electron transfer to the catalyst surface. Qiu et al. integrated tailored active sites into precisely engineered structures, embedding CuO x active materials into TiO2 nanotube reactors (TiO2 NTs/CuO x ), thereby promote the activity and selectivity to NO3RR [93]. The FE of ammonia experiences a substantial increase owing to restricted diffusion within the nano-constrained space and the mitigation of NO2 − intermediates, whereas catalysts lacking nanotube geometry exhibit limited capability to convert the toxic intermediate nitrite. A wide range of materials, encompassing both precious and transition metals, have been extensively utilized in the electrochemical NO3RR for ammonia synthesis, and yield promising results. However, consensus on the optimal catalyst has yet to be reached. Therefore, it is essential to advance our understanding of the underlying catalytic mechanisms and incorporate theoretical computational methods to identify catalysts that are both efficient and stable. 2.3 Design of electrocatalytic devices for potential industrial NO3RR Currently, the majority of research on ammonia synthesis is confined to laboratory settings. Prior investigations have outlined numerous factors necessary for industrial-scale NO3RR ammonia synthesis [49,51,100], encompassing the stability of catalysts, the development of continuous flow electrolyzers suitable for industrial production, energy efficiency of production, product purification methods, and the applicability to industrial wastewater conditions. The stability of the catalyst is essential for sustaining long-term industrial production. However, current stability tests reported in the literature typically span less than 50 h [101,102], falling short of meeting industrial production requirements. To address this challenge, researchers are actively engaged in the development of catalysts capable of meeting long-term production targets. Chen et al. reported a high-performance catalyst comprising ruthenium-dispersed copper nanowires [103]. The catalyst achieves a current of 1 A cm−2 with a high FE of 93%, which meet the standard of industrialization. Moreover, a long-term test for the stability of the catalyst demonstrates that the catalyst can operate reliably for over 100 h, retaining an excellent performance for NO3RR. Fan et al. reported a hollow cobalt phosphide nanosphere electrocatalyst, exhibiting remarkably electrocatalytic activity with a high stability of 123 h in the NO3RR [104]. Further investigation elucidated that the generation of active hydrogen on the surface of the catalyst supports the hydrogenation reaction of nitrogen intermediates, thereby facilitating the rapid formation of ammonia. In addition to catalyst considerations, the design of the electrolyzer play a crucial role in realizing industrial-scale NO3RR for ammonia synthesis. Most existing research centers around H-cell, which comprising two chambers containing electrolytes separated by an ion exchange membrane. The greater distance between the anode and cathode in these electrolyzers leads to higher internal resistance and consequently lower energy efficiency. Moreover, most H-cell lack the capability for automatic electrolyte replacement, rendering them unsuitable for industrial use. MEA, prevalent in fuel cells, feature a low internal resistance where the membrane is tightly compressed with the electrode [105]. Contrasted with the H-cell, MEA exhibit lower internal resistance, enabling the attainment of high current density at reduced cell voltage (Fig. 5 a). Moreover, MEA boast a simpler structure and are better suited for large-scale electrochemical operations. Therefore, a number of studies have adopted MEA as the electrolyzer for NO3RR. Li et al. achieved a current density of 400 mA cm−2 for NH3 synthesis via NO3RR in a MEA electrolyzer with proton exchange membrane with an OD-Cu model catalyst [105]. Huang et al. investigated the influence of the reaction microenvironment on ammonia synthesis [106]. Their study revealed that a bipolar membrane MEA system could provide more proton to promote the hydrogenation process of the intermediates than the standard MEA setup, thus increased the production of ammonia by around 576%. Li et al. employed an enlarged MEA electrolytic cell (36 cm2, shown in Fig. 5b) to accomplish large-scale ammonia synthesis, achieving a maximum total current of 15 A [107]. Besides MEA, some new electrolyzer have also been applied. Shahdi et al. presented a high-performance electrolyzer employing ultra-high alkalinity electrolyte NaOH-KOH-H2O for cost-effective NH3 electrosynthesis at 100 °C (Fig. 5c) [108]. Utilizing a Fe-Cu-Ni three-way catalyst, the device achieved a FE of 92.5% and a current density of 3,000 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 3.83 V. The increase in electrolyzer area and current density leads to the rapid consumption of raw materials, necessitating the timely replenishment of nitrate and water. Fortunately, most electrocatalytic production occurs at room temperature and pressure, simplifying the replenishment process. Generally, continuous production can be achieved by adding pipes that allow fresh electrolyte to flow into the cathode chamber and for spent electrolyte to flow out after the reaction. Many studies have adopted similar methods to achieve continuous production [103,105,106,109]. Chen et al. modified the H-cell by adding an inlet and outlet for the electrolyte in the cathode chamber, enabling continuous reaction [103]. Huang et al. utilized a bipolar membrane (BPM)-based membrane electrode assembly (MEA) system to achieve continuous production, integrating the water treatment system with the carbon capture system to synthesize ammonia under actual conditions [106]. After achieving long-term production stability and large-scale, continuous operation of electrolyzers, the technical economy of the system will be the next goal to achieve industrialized production. Generally speaking, the energy efficiency of the system is directly related to the overall voltage of the electrolyzer, so reducing the overall voltage can help reduce production costs [110,111]. In traditional reaction system, the OER at the anode consumes significant energy. Therefore, finding alternatives to the OER at the anode is a viable approach to reduce energy consumption [112]. Li et al. implemented a coupling strategy between the glycerol oxidation reaction and NO3RR, enhancing both ammonia production efficiency in the electrolysis system and yielding formic acid, a valuable product, at the anode [107]. Furthermore, Guo et al. innovatively proposed replacing the anode with the zinc oxidation reaction [97]. The Zn-NO3 − battery can spontaneously perform NO3RR while outputting electrical energy. Researchers further improved battery and electrode materials to achieve better performance. Zhang et al. proposed an alkaline-acidic hybrid Zn-NO3 − battery (Fig. 5e) [113]. The bipolar membrane creates a pH difference between the cathode and anode chambers, thus maintains the OCV of Zn-NO3 − cell at 1.99 V, which is higher than any previously reported values for this type of battery (Fig. 5f). Industrial production entails more nuanced considerations than the conditions in laboratory, such as product separation and purification. In small distributed plants powered by renewable energy, NH3 production rates are typically lower compared to traditional large-scale, centralized production methods, and due to the low concentration of the product, it is difficult to collect directly from the electrolyte. Therefore, it is necessary to develop efficient and low-energy methods for product extraction. Chen et al. leveraged the high vapor pressure of ammonia in an alkaline environment to devise an air stripping technique to extract ammonia from the electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 6 (a) [103]. Ultimately, over 99.7% of the produced ammonia was effectively removed and only 0.55 ppm of ammonia was left. This stripping technique has also been employed and reported by other researchers [112,114]. In addition, the composition of the electrolyte is also a crucial aspect that cannot be overlooked in practical applications. Most current studies utilize simulated electrolytes and overlook the potential interference of various ions present in actual wastewater. In response to this issue, Qin et al. investigated electroplating wastewater containing copper nitrate [115]. They developed an electrochemical membrane system capable of recovering copper while converting excess NO3 − into NH4NO3 chemical products. Their findings underscored the effectiveness of this approach in treating complex electroplating wastewater. Furthermore, Zheng et al. constructed a 500 L pilot reactor equipped with a self-activating nickel electrode for ammonia synthesis via NO3RR in a real wastewater environment from the chemical plant (Fig. 6b–d) [116]. The results demonstrated that pilot-scale cathodes were advantageous for converting nitrate to ammonia, yielding significantly high conversion rates, FE, and long-term stability. In addition to process design, another crucial factor to be considered in industrial production is economics. Shahdi et al. confirmed through techno-economic analysis (TEA) that efficient catalysts can effectively increase the energy efficiency for ammonia synthesis, thereby decreasing the cost of NH3 [108]. Additionally, Chen et al. utilized a similar membrane-free alkaline electrolyzer (MFAEL) to significantly lower device costs [117]. TEA calculations further indicate that it is promising to increase the energy efficiency by reducing the cell voltage of NO3 RR. In order to achieve this purpose, Li et al. conducted an economic evaluation of the anode organic oxidation coupling system and found that reducing the operating voltage could result in energy savings of approximately 1.4 × 103 kW h per ton of NH3, translating to cost savings of $348 per ton of NH3 (Fig. 5d) [107]. Additionally, the formic acid production at the anode (approximately $1,200 per ton) further enhanced the techno-economic value of this coupled system, improving from approximately $2,629 per ton of NH3 to $1,217 per ton of NH3. Moreover, Hu et al. employed a hydrogen oxidation reaction to replace the OER at the anode, achieving an impressive cell voltage of 1.2 V [118]. TEA analysis indicates that this method is economically feasible for industrial synthesis. Samaroo et al. systematically studied the costs of treatment of nitrate pollution directly and that of NO3RR ammonia synthesis [119]. Their analysis concludes that the system is not economically viable without significant support. Overcoming the challenge of high initial fixed capital investment will require substantial backing from the government entity. Despite extensive research efforts, current studies remain inadequate to meet the demands of large-scale production. Advancements in device development, catalyst and device stability, product extraction and collection, and the enhancement of economic efficiency are crucial for promoting the industrial-scale electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia via electrocatalysis NO3RR. Furthermore, the requirements for catalysts should not be neglect. The indicators of performance such as Ampere-level current density, near 100% FE and the stability are fundamental for industrial production. 3 C–N coupling for urea and other high-value products 3.1 Synthesis of urea As the first artificially synthesized organic substance, urea has found widespread applications in both agriculture and industry [120,121]. On industrial production, urea is a downstream product of ammonia. Similar to the synthesis of ammonia, urea synthesis involves the reaction under high temperature (150–200 °C) and high pressure (15–25 MPa) [122,123]. Electrocatalysis offers a distinct advantage over thermal catalytic urea synthesis by enabling the direct C–N coupling from raw materials (CO2, NO3 −), thereby reducing the need for intermediate product storage and transportation, streamlining the process, and potentially lowering associated costs [124]. However, the exploration of urea synthesis is currently hindered by the diversity of its reaction pathway and the presence of various competing reactions (NO3RR, CO2RR, and HER), which has limited progress to a relatively superficial stage [30]. This section will delve into the current theoretical advancements in urea synthesis and present the latest findings from catalyst research, aimed at high efficiency and high selectivity in urea synthesis. 3.1.1 Recent theorical advances of urea synthesis Electrocatalytic urea synthesis consists of a multi-step electrochemical process and chemical steps [125]. Yu et al. summarized the pathways and key intermediates of urea synthetic, as shown in Fig. 7 [120]. Besides the competitive products generated from NO3RR (including NH3 and NO2 −), CO2RR (including CO, CH4, and CH3OH), and HER (H2), the process of C–N coupling yields various other compounds, including H3CNH2 and C2H7N. Given the intricate and varied pathways involved in urea synthesis, understanding the C–N coupling mechanism in electrochemical urea synthesis through comprehensive research holds significant importance. According to the Fig. 7, CO2 and NO3 − undergo conversion into diverse intermediates through PCET, including *CO2, *CO, NO2, *NO, *H2NOH, *NH, and *NH2. Subsequently, C–N coupling reactions ensue among these intermediates, primarily involving the coupling between CO* and NH2*, CO* and NH*, CO* and NH2OH*, CO2* and NO2*, CO2* and NH2*, and so on. The divergence in reaction pathways influences the composition and distribution of the products. For instance, *CO and *NH2 intermediates are more readily converted into CO and NH3 products, thereby competing with urea synthesis [126,127]. Meanwhile, the early occurrence of *CO2 and *NO2 coupling in the reaction is believed to mitigate the formation of competitive products to some extent [128]. Nonetheless, the aforementioned assertion remains only partially confirmed, and the selection of reaction pathways and the transformation mechanisms of key intermediates are still unclear, requiring further exploration. In this regard, the integration of theoretical calculations with in-situ spectroscopic characterization techniques will enhance the understanding of the C–N coupling reaction mechanism. 3.1.2 Advances in urea synthesis catalysts Ferromagnetic metal-based catalyst has garnered extensive attention in the realms of NO3RR and CO2RR [129–131], thus prompting widespread interest in their application to C–N coupling reactions as well. Zhang et al. reported a diatomic catalyst featuring bonded Fe-Ni pairs [125]. The bonded Fe-Ni pairs enhance C–N coupling thermodynamics and kinetics, resulting in an excellent urea synthesis performance. Fan et al. employed cobalt nanoparticles anchored on carbon nanosheets (Co NPs@C) as catalyst electrodes [132]. The Co NPs@C catalyst exhibited outstanding activity in urea production, surpassing both Co NPs and C nanosheet counterparts, while demonstrating remarkable stability. Computational analyses indicate that the synergistic interplay between Co NPs and C is responsible for the superior urea electrosynthesis performance achieved through the concurrent reduction of NO3 − and CO2 processes. Due to its distinctive adsorption properties and catalytic prowess, Cu-based catalysts have found extensive application in NO3RR and CO2RR, particularly in the synthesis of hydrocarbons and multi-carbon products [133–137]. Wei et al. reported the catalytic synthesis of urea using copper single atoms decorated on CeO2 supports, and Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) demonstrated the reorganization of copper single atoms (Cu1) into clusters (Cu4) during the electrocatalysis process [138]. Moreover, high potential promotes the adsorption and consersion of CO2 and NO3 − on Cu1-CeO2, thereby facilitating C–N coupling. Shin et al. conducted a systematic investigation into the impact of copper atomic spacing on the C–N coupling synthesis of urea [139]. In-situ X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES)/Raman experiments revealed that the catalyst performance is unaffected whether it is oxidized, but is influenced by the atomic-level gap of the nanoparticle faces. To explore the reaction pathway for urea synthesis, Qiu et al. conducted in situ experiments and discovered that *NO2 and *CO are key intermediates in the formation of C–N bonds on the Cu–O-Si surface [140]. Theoretical calculations revealed that *CO is the most thermodynamically favorable species for coupling with *NO2. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism involving *CO and *NO2 likely proceeds through more stable intermediates or transition states compared to reactions involving *NH or *NH2. Another widely used catalyst is Ti-based catalyst. Saravanakumar et al. firstly to proposed and confirmed the activity of TiO2 in the electrocatalytic synthesis of urea [127]. In comparison to gas diffusion electrodes loaded with Zn and Cu, the TiO2-Nafion electrode demonstrates urea production at a more positive potential. Huang et al. utilized MIL-125-NH2 as the precursor to synthesize a TiO2 electrocatalyst (designated as TiO2-C) [141]. In-situ spectroscopy detected the *NH2COO intermediate, with no *CO generation observed. This suggests that the C–N coupling on the TiO2-C surface likely stems from the direct interaction between *NH2 and free CO2. Due to the weak conductivity of TiO2 and constraints in mass transfer at individual active sites, TiO2 is frequently incorporated into bimetallic catalysts with other active metals to harness synergistic effects among various catalytic components. Zheng et al. anchored single-atom Cu onto TiO2 and engineered proximal bimetallic Cu and Ti active sites [142]. DFT calculations (Fig. 8 ) and in-situ characterizations revealed that the Cu site effectively catalyzes CO2 reduction to *CO, while the neighboring Ti site facilitates nitrate reduction to the *NH2 intermediate on the SAC Cu-TiO2. The intimate proximity of Cu and Ti sites reduces the distance between *CO and *NH2 coupling intermediates, enhancing the C–N bonding for urea synthesis. Zn has garnered extensive attention as an electrocatalyst for C–N coupling urea synthesis owing to its exceptional catalytic prowess. Luo et al. employed DFT calculations to scrutinize the reaction pathways of NO3 − and CO2 co-electrolysis on specific single-component metals [143]. Their analysis revealed that the energy required for the C–N bond formation step is considerably lower on the Zn surface compared to Cu or Ag. Leveraging these findings, a Zn/Cu mixed catalyst was meticulously designed and synthesized. In situ spectroscopy alongside computational analyses indicated that the hybrid Zn/Cu catalyst possesses the unique capability to independently modulate the energy barrier of the initial C–N bond formation step and the protonation step from *CO2NH2 to *COOHNH2, thus facilitating a relay catalytic pathway. Meng et al. demonstrated that the formation and coupling of *CO and *NH2 intermediates on the Zn catalyst surface are the primary steps in the initial C–N coupling during the urea synthesis process [126]. In particular, In has garnered attention for its distinctive performance in C–N coupling reactions. Lv et al. discovered that the In(OH)3{100} plane exhibits a low energy barrier, initiating the unique step of coupling *NO2 and *CO2 intermediates directly, contrasting starkly with *NO2 or *CO2 protonation alone [128]. Additionally, the protonation of *CO2NH2 emerged as a potentially pivotal step in the entire urea production process (Fig. 9 ) [144]. Li et al. similarly revealed that on the {100} crystal plane of the ln-O-x-O-ln (x = C or N) catalyst, *NO2 and *CO2 intermediates can be efficiently absorbed and activated on the surface, then direct coupled instead of protonated [145]. Moreover, the introduction of oxygen vacancies (VO) lowers the energy barrier for *CO2NH2 protonation, resulting in relatively high activity. Efficient catalysts are crucial for achieving urea synthesis via C–N coupling from nitrate and carbon dioxide. However, the current catalysts are limited by both selectivity and activity, as evidenced by their low FE and low current density. Therefore, it is still necessary to design and synthesize high-performance catalysts. Given that relevant research is still in its infancy, large-scale screening of materials is essential. Theoretical calculation methods, such as DFT, and new techniques, such as high-throughput screening, can significantly promoting this process. 3.2 Synthesis of products beyond ammonia and urea In addition to ammonia and urea, nitrate can also undergo electrocatalytic conversion into other high-value products, such as amino acids and alkylamines. Amino acids and alkylamines serve as crucial chemical raw materials utilized across various sectors including industry and agriculture. Their applications span diverse domains such as food production, pharmaceutical manufacturing, pesticide formulation, and solvent synthesis [146,147]. Recently, initial efforts and theoretical investigations have been initiated to explore the C–N coupling for electrocatalytic synthesis of amino acids and alkyl amines. Amine such as methylamine and ethylamine is another product synthesized via CO2 and NO3 −. Wu et al. was the first to report the electrocatalytic synthesis of methylamine using CO2 and NO3 − under ambient conditions (Fig. 10 ) [148]. The formation of C–N bond primarily relies on the coupling of hydroxylamine (NH2OH) and formaldehyde (HCOH) intermediate. Jing et al. discovered that the lowest barrier for C–N coupling occurs through desorbed HCHO and NH2OH, rather than when these intermediates are adsorbed on the catalyst [149]. Tao et al. pioneered the electrochemical synthesis of acetaldoxime and ethylamine through the co-reduction of CO2 and NO3 − by oxide-derived copper catalysts [150]. The synthesis of amino acids typically involves the C–N coupling of organic acids and NO3 −. Kim et al. utilized CO2-derived oxalic acid and nitrate to synthesize glycine [151]. Through thorough detection, analysis, and experimentation on competitive products, they deduced that the electrochemical synthesis of glycine involves the formation and reduction of acetaldoxime. Specifically, the initial step comprises the synthesis of glyoxylic acid via oxalic acid. Subsequently, hydroxylamine converted from nitrate nucleophilically attacks the electrophilic carbon center of glyoxylic acid, leading to dehydration and the formation of acetaldoxime. Finally, the glyoxylic acid oxime spontaneously reduced to glycine, completing the entire process. As shown in Fig. 11 , Wu et al. achieved the integrated tandem synthesis of alanine utilizing pyruvate (PA) and NO3 − catalyzed by PdCu nanobead wires (PdCu NBWs) [152]. In situ characterization and product analysis showed the NO3 − reduced to the NH2OH intermediate on the Cu surface, which subsequently spontaneously couples with PA to produce acetone oxime. Subsequently, Pd promotes the electrocatalytic conversion of acetone oxime to alanine. It can be seen that electrocatalysis primarily facilitates the reduction of pivotal groups and C–N coupling during amino acid synthesis, with the type of product largely dictated by the carbon source. Xian et al. corroborated this perspective [153]. Drawing from their experimental findings on amino acid synthesis from NO, they proposed a mechanism for amino acid formation. Initially, NO is adsorbed onto the AD-Fe/NC catalyst, followed by its reduction to NH2OH. NH2OH promptly engages in CN coupling with α-keto acid to generate oxime, subsequently undergoing hydrogenation to yield amino acid. Employing various α-keto acids for reaction with NO resulted in the production of corresponding α-amino acids, underscoring the universality of the aforementioned reaction pathway. Encouragingly, nitrogen sources can be interchanged with NO3 − and NO2 −, with valine being detectable even when employing 3-methyl-2-oxobutyric acid as the carbon source alongside a 500 mM NO3 − electrolyte and NO2, in lieu of a NO-saturated electrolyte. Due to the lack of relevant research, the reaction mechanisms, pathways, and identification of intermediates remain unclear and require further exploration. Current research should focus on systematically summarizing the C–N coupling mechanism and analyzing and verifying possible reaction pathways, guiding the screening and design of effective catalysts. 4 Conclusions Effective electrocatalytic converting nitrates from the wastewater into high-value products holds the potential to alleviate environmental challenges and establish artificial nitrogen cycles. Moreover, combined with CO2RR, C–N coupling can be realized under mild conditions, thereby curbing fossil fuel consumption and mitigating carbon emissions during the production process. In present work, we reviewed recent advances in electrocatalytic NO3RR, including identifying and designing electrocatalyst, as well as understanding of the reaction mechanism for different products such as ammonia and urea. Furthermore, industrial electrocatalytic devices for ammonia synthesis and the techno-economic analysis are also discussed. To advance the development of promising electrocatalytic NO3RR, here we delineate the bottlenecks and offer perspectives on potential pathways to address current challenges and capitalize on future opportunities. (1) Elucidating the reaction mechanism. While the existing NO3RR ammonia synthesis reaction pathway is broadly understood, the adsorption, conversion, and desorption behavior of surface-active intermediate species on various catalysts remain unclear. Advanced in-situ/operando characterization techniques can facilitate the direct identification of reaction intermediates, thereby deepening our comprehension of reaction pathways and catalytic structure-activity relationships. (2) Rational design of cost-effective and efficient catalysts. The utilization of precious metals, intricate synthesis methodologies, and reliance on chemical reagents render many existing catalysts prohibitively expensive and unsuitable for industrial-scale applications. To address this, efforts should focus on minimizing or circumventing the use of precious metals and employing easily scalable synthesis techniques. Simultaneously, the performance of the catalysts must remain at a high level to meet the demands of industrial application, that is, achieving ampere-level current density with high FE and long-term stability is fundamental for stable and large-scale production. (3) Development and evaluation of novel electrolyzers. Most current studies rely on lab-scale H-cell electrolyzers, which typically feature limited reaction areas and high internal resistance. Conversely, emerging electrolyzer designs, such as flow cells and MEA electrolyzers, offer reduced internal resistance and enhanced scalability of the reaction area. (4) Application and evaluation in actual industrial scenarios. Compared to operation under laboratory conditions, the complexities of real production environment and the necessary auxiliary infrastructure are often overlooked. While some studies have highlighted the potential use of nitrate in industrial or domestic wastewater as a raw material source, along with solar or wind energy for powering the reactions, there is a lack of systematic research on the effects of nitrate content in wastewater, pH values and interfering ions on NO3RR, along with the adaptability of electrocatalytic systems to fluctuating energy inputs remains understudied. Angjian Wu is an associate professor of Energy and Environmental Engineering at Zhejiang University, China. He received his Ph.D. degree from Zhejiang University in 2017. His current research interests focus on the development of plasma technology and electrocatalysis, including CO2 conversion, H2 production, and nitrogen fixation.

coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) powered by renewable energy offers a promising approach for simultaneously reutilization of nitrate and synthesizing high-value products. Nevertheless, theoretical understanding of reaction mechanism was relative illusive, which is indispensable to rationally design of efficient catalysts. Besides, tuning the reaction microenvironment along with the scale-up device development is essential to promote the industrial deployment of electrocatalytic nitrate conversion, while relative research was overlooked. In this regard, recent advances in ammonia synthesis are firstly summarized, including the identification of active sites, exploration of the underlying reaction mechanisms, electrolyzer design and technical-economic analysis. Furthermore, electrocatalytic C–N coupling based on NO3RR to produce higher-value products such as urea and amino acids are also reviewed, to extend the application potential and economic feasibility. Finally, we highlight the existing challenges and the demand of future research for NO3RR. This review anticipates to provide insights into synthesis of high-value products via NO3RR, bridging the gap from laboratory research to industrial fabrication.
